data.event: The Washington State Office of Financial Management's 2013 estimate placed the population at 495.
Originally called Bluff Wells, then Judson, now Mesa was a stop on the Ainsworth (now Pasco) to Spokane branch of the Northern Pacific Railroad.

event.title: the stop between Eltopia and Palouse Junction (now

data.event: It was the stop between Eltopia and Palouse Junction (now Connell).

event.title: brought water to the area in 1948

data.event: The Columbia Basin Irrigation Project brought water to the area in 1948.
Mesa was officially incorporated on June 23, 1955.

event.title: Today, Mesa is a small town supported

data.event: Today, Mesa is a small town supported by dryland farming, irrigated farming, and livestock.
In 2008, the city was involved in litigation with former mayor and councilwoman Donna Zink over incorrectly handled public document requests under Washington State's Public Records Act.
